subject: RE: [junit] Programmer Tests and the Database
msgSnippet: ... Robert Koss wrote: That s probably true if the SQL never has to change. If the schema changes, I find it more convenient to go to one known place instead
messageBody:
> On Thu, 6 Feb 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>> Pushing every SQL statement you use out to a ResourceBundle (or other
>> metadata file) is a good idea.
>
> Eww! I know this tends to be a bit of a personal preference, but I far
> prefer to keep my code together when I can. If a statement is used in
> only one place, keeping it where it's used makes the code much easier to
> read, because you don't have to go chasing off into some other file to
> find out what SQL statement is being executed.
>

Robert Koss wrote:
That's probably true if the SQL never has to change. If the schema changes,
I find it more convenient to go to one known place instead of having to
search my entire app for possible changes.

My opinion:
This is a quite convenient and,
according to my experience, effective
approach for dealing with schema evolution.

On the other hand it really hampers development.
But there is also a compromise between
the two positions:
Layer the classes that access the database by
putting all the SQL generation into an inner class.

public class UsingSQL
{
private m_SQL = new SQL();

public void usesSQL()
{
//some processing
m_Statement.execute( m_SQL.selectEmployees() );
//some more processing
}

private class SQL
{
String selectEmployees()
{
return "select * from emp";
}
}
}

So you have all the SQL in place, but it is only limited to a certain
area of your code and doesn't litter the entire class.
Moreover this is a quite convenient way of generating dynamic SQL.
If one adheres to a naming convention for the inner
class (SQL), such classes can be found easily in case of schema evolution.

Just my 2 cents
